content.question:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a twice-differentiable function with <math alttext="f of 0 equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The derivative of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="f prime of x, equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, x squared, minus 2 x, plus 1, close parenthesis "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="negative 2 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 2"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Find all values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="negative 2 less than x, less than 2 "><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> at which <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a critical point. Classify each as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither. Justify your answers.

frqParts.text:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a twice-differentiable function with <math alttext="f of 0 equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The derivative of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="f prime of x, equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, x squared, minus 2 x, plus 1, close parenthesis "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="negative 2 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 2"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Find all values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="negative 2 less than x, less than 2 "><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> at which <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a critical point. Classify each as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither. Justify your answers.

(b)   Use the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 0 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to approximate <math alttext="f of 0.25"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.25</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c)   On the interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 0.25"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>0.25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="f prime of x, is greater than 0 "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="f double prime of x, is less than 0"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the approximation found in part (b) an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext="f of 0.25 "><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.25</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(d)   Using the Mean Value Theorem, explain why the average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="negative 2 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 2"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cannot equal <math alttext="1.25"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
